code.description: A machine readable error code.

200.description: The result of the report usage

400.description: The server cannot or will not process the request due to something that is perceived to be a client error (e.g., malformed request syntax, invalid request message framing, or deceptive request routing).

401.description: Although the HTTP standard specifies "unauthorized", semantically this response means "unauthenticated". That is, the client must authenticate itself to get the requested response.

403.description: The client does not have access rights to the content; that is, it is unauthorized, so the server is refusing to give the requested resource. Unlike 401 Unauthorized, the client's identity is known to the server.

404.description: The server cannot find the requested resource. In the browser, this means the URL is not recognized. In an API, this can also mean that the endpoint is valid but the resource itself does not exist. Servers may also send this response instead of 403 Forbidden to hide the existence of a resource from an unauthorized client. This response code is probably the most well known due to its frequent occurrence on the web.

409.description: This response is sent when a request conflicts with the current state of the server.

412.description: The requested operation cannot be completed because certain conditions were not met. This typically occurs when a required resource state or version check fails.

429.description: The user has sent too many requests in a given amount of time ("rate limiting")

500.description: The server has encountered a situation it does not know how to handle.

post.description: Get payment methods for a customer

200.description: The result of the get payment methods

400.description: The server cannot or will not process the request due to something that is perceived to be a client error (e.g., malformed request syntax, invalid request message framing, or deceptive request routing).

post.description: Sign up a customer for a project

timezone.description: The timezone of the customer, if passed null the system will use the project timezone

defaultCurrency.description: The default currency of the customer, if passed null the system will use the project currency

billingInterval.description: The billing interval of the customer to be used for the subscription. If plan version is provided, the billing interval will be the same as the plan version. If plan slug is provided, the billing interval will be the default billing interval of the plan.

planSlug.description: If the plan id is not provided, you can pass a plan slug and the system will intelligently pick the lastest plan for that slug and sign up the customer for it

sessionId.description: The session id of the customer. This is used to track conversion from pricing pages

planVersionId.description: The plan version the customer is signing up for

featurePlanId.description: The feature plan id of the item

featureSlug.description: The feature slug of the item

isUsage.description: if the item is a usage item

units.description: units of the feature the user is subscribed to

min.description: minimum units of the feature the user is subscribed to

limit.description: limit of the feature the user is subscribed to

config.description: The configuration of the subscription items. This is required if your features are quantity based when the customer needs to set them. Pass as empty if you want the system to automatically set the units from the plan defaults.

externalId.description: The external id you want to associate with the customer. Could be the id of the user in your database

successUrl.description: The success url if the customer signs up. This is the url after the signup process, normally your dashboard

cancelUrl.description: The cancel url if the customer cancels the signup. This is the url after the signup process, normally your login page

200.description: The result of the customer sign up

url.description: The url to redirect the customer to, either to the success or cancel url

customerId.description: The unprice customer id generated by the system for this customer

post.description: Create a payment method for a customer

paymentProvider.description: The payment provider code to use

customerId.description: The unprice customer id generated by the system for this customer

successUrl.description: The success url if the customer signs up

cancelUrl.description: The cancel url if the customer cancels the signup

schema.description: The customer create payment method request

200.description: The result of the customer create payment method

url.description: The url to redirect the customer to, either to the success or cancel url

post.description: Get usage for a customer in a given range

requestBody.description: Body of the request for the get usage

customerId.description: The customer ID if you want to get the usage for a specific customer

projectId.description: The project ID (optional, only available for main projects)

range.description: The range of the usage, last hour, day, week or month

200.description: The result of the get usage

400.description: The server cannot or will not process the request due to something that is perceived to be a client error (e.g., malformed request syntax, invalid request message framing, or deceptive request routing).

401.description: Although the HTTP standard specifies "unauthorized", semantically this response means "unauthenticated". That is, the client must authenticate itself to get the requested response.

403.description: The client does not have access rights to the content; that is, it is unauthorized, so the server is refusing to give the requested resource. Unlike 401 Unauthorized, the client's identity is known to the server.

404.description: The server cannot find the requested resource. In the browser, this means the URL is not recognized. In an API, this can also mean that the endpoint is valid but the resource itself does not exist. Servers may also send this response instead of 403 Forbidden to hide the existence of a resource from an unauthorized client. This response code is probably the most well known due to its frequent occurrence on the web.

409.description: This response is sent when a request conflicts with the current state of the server.

412.description: The requested operation cannot be completed because certain conditions were not met. This typically occurs when a required resource state or version check fails.

429.description: The user has sent too many requests in a given amount of time ("rate limiting")

500.description: The server has encountered a situation it does not know how to handle.

post.description: Get verifications for a customer in a given range

requestBody.description: Body of the request for the get verifications

customerId.description: The customer ID if you want to get the verifications for a specific customer

projectId.description: The project ID (optional, if not provided, the project ID will be the one of the key)

range.description: The range of the verifications, last hour, day, week or month

200.description: The result of the get verifications

400.description: The server cannot or will not process the request due to something that is perceived to be a client error (e.g., malformed request syntax, invalid request message framing, or deceptive request routing).
